title: Update gitIgnore file
Debian packaging.
body:
Hi, I was about to create a Debian package of pypilot to accelerate my OS build time. Then I saw that @sailoog  was also doing the same but with some openplotter's specific config in it.

So in order to avoid work duplication, If there was a implementation neutral Debian package that would exist. Anyone interested could use it as-is or fork the code or write a wrapping meta-package. But share a common base.   

I understand that you use Tiny core and are probably not so motivated about debian packages. But im about to do it anyway for lysmarine. So if you would agree be the owner (and subsequently the benevolent dictator) of the feature/repository. I would prefer to do a Pull request to pypilot and make everyone profit from it then having it for the sole purpose of my project. 

--Fred

title: GPAPB is switching from gps to compass again
body: Hi Sean, Did some minor changes to NMEA and SENSORS to stop switching from gps to compass mode when GPAPB is received. i used isgp instead off ** (as I'm not an experienced python programmer it feels a bit uncomfortable to use an operator as a variable) I did test it on my boat and it stops switching. I manualy typed the changes in GIT, It should be ok but please check and compile them.

so commit 2008b19798a45ba942433305b9b9c61bb8c4686b 
is the one that breaks it for me 

I tried with both 
`apt install python-wxgtk3.0` 
and 
`apt install python-wxgtk4.0`

title: Theming of webclient
body:
Hi, between here and the spring I plan to redo the theme of the webclient so it fit Lysmarine look and feel. 

I can do it on my side as a patch of a fork. 
Or I could put a bit more work in it and PR it as dark theme with a GUI theme switcher or CLI argument.

One one hand I prefer contribution then forks, But on the other hand my need is it have to reflect lysmarine look and feel ( mainly based on adapta-nokto work  https://github.com/adapta-project/adapta-gtk-theme ) so it's not much of a common goal. 

So before I start, would you be interested in integrating such PR or you prefer that I keep it on my side  ? As in a what make more sense for pypilot project.

title: Fix reading port from config file for the pypilot web
body:
On RPI, armbian and linux mint. I was unable to read port from the configuration file.  

The ~ sign was not working to resolve the path so used the getenv('HOME')

json lib was missing

and I had to modify the example in the doc, single quotes and square brackets where causing json.reads error.  


Im not used to code python so I hope did it the right way.

title: Add explicit config file location + rephrasing
Pypilot and calibration ui adjust to make it useful on 800x480 screens

Curent Master UI was not comfortable on 800x480 screens
1) light changes in pypilot UI and Calibration windows sizes
2) Adjusted elements sizes alignment calibration screen
3) +50% increase size of the Boat in alignment calibration screen to make it better visible on the screen. Downside - sailboat mast top does not fit in the frame

title: Driver type is now set at compile time, rather than run time
body:
Set DRIVER to the kind of driver you have.  Frees two pins that were
used for run-time checking of driver type.

title: Added missing backslash to fix wrong dead time when running at 4MHz
body: Preprocessor was giving warning.

title: Squash compiler warning about unused var for lock bits
Fix typos from errant search and replace rename
make weathersensor code compilable, variable name misprint fix
Motor Driver - Code Style and Timers
body:
Hi there,

I love how much work has been put into this all to make this work and open source.
The whole day, I have been reading the Arduino code for the motor driver and added a ton of documentation, changed the layout a little bit and organized the code based on configuration and pin assignments as well as important stuff at the top and tools etc. at the bottom of the file.

However, I wonder, why you are using all the AVR native functions and not the Arduino build in libraries. Is it really necessary to drive this at 60Hz? Is it really necessary to run certain things at exactly 30Hz? Or 50Hz? 
Why did you decide to configure the code by using external jumpers if the code needs to be modified to fit ones needs anyways?

I guess I would like to propose to make this a bit more modular. I want to implement compatibility with the [IBT 2 H-BRIDGE](http://www.robotpower.com/downloads/BTS7960_v1.1_2004-12-07.pdf). It's cheap and powerful but it needs[ two PWM ](https://www.handsontec.com/dataspecs/module/BTS7960%20Motor%20Driver.pdf)and two enable lines but it also provides two current sense / fault lines. Integrating this into your code seems incredibly complex as it requires detailed knowledge of the AVR timers. It looks like I can't just use analogWrite() to do this because you're running custom timers.

If this code could be restructured to use #defines in a config.h to do the general configuration, a pins.h to do all pin assignments and remove all the #if 1 or #if 0 ... #endif stuff, and removal of all the custom timers, it would already help a lot. At present, without further documentation, I would love to rewrite all this to use standard Arduino functions instead of lowest level AVR code. I mean, who really uses a bare metal H-Bridge these days that would require all this in the first place?

Please don't take this the wrong way! I know people are using and loving your work! And I'm here for a reason: I want to use OpenPlotter and PyPilot, too! However, in order to make this motor driver more modifiable, we need to clean up the code and write more documentation :)

Makefile:66: recipe for target 'obj/weathersensors.o' failed
make: *** [obj/weathersensors.o] Error 1

title: MPU-9250 not detected
body:
Running `python pypilot/boatimu.py` with a MPU-9250 plugged gives me _No IMU detected_, even though `sudo i2cdetect -y 1` finds it on 0x68.
Moreover the output of 
`watch -n.1 python gyro.py`
gives me some confidence that the MPU is healthy.

[gyro.py](https://tutorials-raspberrypi.com/measuring-rotation-and-acceleration-raspberry-pi/)

title: syntax error
body:
https://github.com/pypilot/pypilot/blob/f0ad106e88d826be0b2a915ed6e4a14d8a3a0155/pypilot/nmea.py#L159

It should be `try:`

title: GPAPB with empty data will crash NMEA communication
body: As (Garmin) plotters produce GPAPB with empty data when no active waypoint it will crash nmea communication by doing a float on an empty string without try except. With RMC and MWV there is a try except only on APB it is missing.

body:

```
failed to load pywavefront: glXSwapIntervalMESA is not exported by the available OpenGL driver.  MESA_swap_control is required for this functionality.
```

OpenGL is enabled by default in RPi4.

title: error installing
body:
```
File "build/bdist.linux-armv7l/egg/pypilot/servo.py", line 600
    if result & ServoTelemetry.EEPROM && self.use_eeprom.value: # occurs only once after connecting
                                       ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```
Replacing && by & removes the error.

title: Webapp Basic/Simple/Learning selection not filtering Gain choices.
body:
What I believe is an attempt to filter for the most important Gains and reduce clutter actually results in an even larger list of Gains onscreen (D.basic D. learning etc)

Unless I've misunderstood the purpose of this select list, perhaps choices would better be labeled differently:

quick start, basic, advanced?

Or could use "more" and "less" to expand the list.

title: Webapp Gains are not saved (or aren't reflected visually upon refresh)
body: I am not sure if it is just the slider position visually that doensn't keep, but the gains don't seem to be kept when adjusted from the webapp.

The sliding button on the webapp does not show that it has changed (turn green, etc) when tapped. The page must be refreshed. 

This same problem effects usability of the app in many areas. 

Running Openplotter with latest Pypilot from Github. Browser on iOS, Android, and Openplotter.

title: void read_anenometer() issue
Implement volts/amps correction by offset and gain compensation.
body:
The offset and gain values are stored in EEPROM and can be modified
by the clients using special codes.

In addition, a few other parameters (max controller temp,
max motor temp, rudder range, max slew) are also stored in EEPROM
making the controller safe even if no client is connected.

title: Implement ADC correction by offset and gain compensation.
body: The offset and gain values are stored in EEPROM.
